data.title: improve exception configuration experience
data.body:
Since the debug protocol now supports more flexible configuration of exceptions, we should consider to surface this in the VS Code Debugger UI.

See https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-debugadapter-node/issues/64

data.title: Move files with intellisense
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.0
- OS Version: Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Move a File into an other folder in project

Is there a way of moving files without having to update dozens of files afterwards manually?
If i rename a file, the editor opens all files linked to that file with a proposed change. Is this possible for moving files, too? https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-tips-and-tricks/issues/34

data.title: Improve tabSize configuration based off file types [Feature Request]
How do I compile vscode?
data.body:
I've cloned the source. I've run scripts/npm install. I've run npm run watch. I've tried gulp vscode-win32.
These all build the typescript stuff, but nothing builds the executable. I can't find any information on this, because everytime I google "how to compile vscode" or anything similar, I find hundreds of articles about "how to compile stuff in vscode".

The documentation here: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute is extremely lacking. I've done everything it says and have not gotten anything built.

data.title: Save all pastes contents of unsaved file into current tab

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: MacOS 10.12.2


Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open two existing files in the editor
2. Make a small change to one, do not save
3. Move to the tab of the unchanged file
4. Hit cmd-alt-s

The files are saved, and the contents of the changed file pasted into the unchanged file.
See attached screen capture for example on newly created project
[VSCodeSaveAllError.mov.zip](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/684074/VSCodeSaveAllError.mov.zip)

data.title: directory globs in launch.json "outFiles" cause breakpoints not to trigger on Windows 10.
data.body:
- VSCode Version:  1.8.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  With the following config in launch.json 

    {
      "type": "node",
      "request": "launch",
      "name": "Generate Model Types",
      "program": "${workspaceRoot}/src/lib/gentypes.ts",
      "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
      "outFiles": [ "${workspaceRoot}/src/dist/lib/*.js" ],
      "sourceMaps": true
    },

then breakpoints trigger ok for all .ts files in the ".../src/lib" folder.

2.  If I change the outFiles entry instead to read:

      "outFiles": [ "${workspaceRoot}/src/dist/**/*.js" ],

then only breakpoints in the program entry file (".../src/lib/gentypes.ts") will trigger.  Other files can be stepped into ok from the entry file, and breakpoints can be set therein that appear active and ok (no sourcemap warning messages etc.), but they simply fail to trigger.  

I tried changed the above to the traditional Windows style instead:

      "outFiles": [ "${workspaceRoot}\\src\\dist\\**\\*.js" ],

but still no cigar.

Thanks.

data.title: Add F4 shortcut for navigating search results
data.body: Fixes #17324. @sandy081, you've worked in this area, let me know if this is the right approach.

data.title: Feature Request: make sidebar folder toggle behaviour configurable
data.body:
When going through the file tree in sidebar, I have a tendency to click on a folder to mark where I'm looking at. Same thing when I want to create a file under a folder

The current behaviour is to toggle open/closed it in a single click and sometimes it can be quite annoying for me, since I still want to keep it in the same way as before. With current behaviour, I need to click one more time to return it to previous state.

Is it possible to make a folder selected in a single click and toggle state in double click? Can make it configurable and leave the default as current behaviour

data.title: Feature: Tooltip drill down
Allow Blank Lines inside of Script Tags in Markdown
data.body:
For the markdown:

```markdown
**bold**

<script>

window.addEventListener('scroll', function(e) { 
    window.parent.alert('**should not be bold**');
})

</script>

**bold**
```

The entire contents of the script tag should be rendered as JavaScript. Currently, any blank lines interrupt the JS script block and cause it to be rendered as markdown:

![screen shot 2017-01-03 at 5 28 46 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12821956/21629147/479c7206-d1da-11e6-9294-d9f9a4ba534c.png)


![screen shot 2017-01-03 at 5 28 53 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12821956/21629141/3fdc7ba6-d1da-11e6-862e-24ad69abe141.png)

data.title: Tsc task output limited in osx

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: MacOS 10.11.6

We are converting a project over to TypeScript at the moment and have a strange issue which is causing some confusion. When any team member using macos builds through VSCode they get somewhere between 50-150 build errors shown in the `Tasks` output and problem window, on windows machines we get the full ~1300

It seems that VSCode on Mac just doesn't capture all of the output from the `tsc` process. Any ideas on what to try?

data.title: Explore providing an API for providing progress information
data.body:
Some extensions have a need to make the user aware of long running operations that usually happen in the background. Here are a few examples.
- the Java extension indicates the background installation of the Java language server
- the Azure Functions extensions indicates the generation of code
- the spell checking extension indicates checking in progress
- the Python extension indicates running unit tests

Since VS Code does not provide an API extensions invent their own way of progress reporting usually using status bar contributions. Some use words, some use ascii art, some use glyphs. Some show the progress on the right side, some in the left side. This does not 

We'll explore what kind of progress reporting capabilities are most helpful to extensions and how we could expose those in our API.

data.title: [feature-request] Let's make this open source project great with VB6 support
data.body:
This is a feature request.

Finally we have an open source Visual Studio, and it's awesome. Let's make it even more awesome by providing support for the forsaken - VB6 developers. The classic VB6 IDE doesn't support ctrl navigation, doesn't support mouse wheel scrolling, which makes it totally hard to use. Let's build something on top of this open source Visual Studio to save those still struggling with this still widely used, hard to stop and replace programming language.
